channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Palermo, a Catholic Saint Joins the Hindu Pantheon
item.description: The Sicilian capital, Palermo, has a long history of cultural melding. Its new arrivals from Sri Lanka have embraced St. Rosalia.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Gianni Cipriano
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

item.title: In Gaza, Even Poetry and Toilets Aren’t Safe From Thieves
item.description: Israel’s assault has driven Hamas underground, but for nearly two million Gazans, what followed in its wake is a lawlessness that is undermining communal trust.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A makeshift street market in May in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza.

item.title: Amid Heavy Industry, Canada’s Newest (and Tiniest) National Park
item.description: The creation of an urban national park on an unprepossessing parcel of land in the automaking hub of Windsor, Ontario, is also meant to serve as an act of Indigenous reconciliation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Tara Walton
item.media:description: The surprising site of Canada’s newest national park, along the Detroit River in Windsor, Ontario, a city best known for automaking.

item.title: Protests Again Rock Bangladesh, Weeks After a Deadly Crackdown
item.description: As curfews and restrictions on communication were loosened, anger over the deadly suppression of previous protests began flaring up once more.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A protest in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Friday over Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her government to demand justice for the more than 200 people killed in last month’s demonstrations.

item.title: To Lam Confirmed as Vietnam’s Top Leader
item.description: Mr. Lam had been filling the post of general secretary temporarily since the death of his predecessor in July. Now he is in position to consolidate power.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Vietnam’s president, To Lam, at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi on Thursday, is best known for implementing an anticorruption drive.

item.title: The U.K. Riots Were Fomented Online. Will Social Media Companies Act?
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer called out social media groups for the misinformation on their platforms that sparked violent clashes this week. But holding them accountable is tough.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Riot police officers attempting to control violent unrest in Southport, England, on Tuesday, hours after a vigil for three girls killed in a stabbing attack.

item.title: Iran Arrests Dozens After Killing of Hamas Leader Haniyeh
item.description: Iran has begun a sweeping investigation into the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, with its intensity a sign of how damaging and shocking the security failure was.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral for Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran on Friday; the Hamas leader was assassinated in Iran’s capital on Wednesday.

item.title: In Canada as a Girl, Kamala Harris Yearned for California
item.description: Ms. Harris went north as a 12-year-old when her mother was recruited to conduct breast-cancer research, but California was always on her mind. The experience of a Canadian friend inspired her to become a prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

item.title: Germany Grapples With ‘Difficult Decision’ in Prisoner Swap
item.description: By releasing a convicted assassin, Germany played a critical role in securing the freedom of 16 people held in Russia. But the decision has raised questions about political influence in legal cases.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany overcame opposition to the idea of freeing an assassin in a prisoner exchange with Russia. “No one made this decision to deport a murderer sentenced to life lightly,” he said.

item.title: Myanmar Junta Evades Sanctions and Increases Airstrikes
item.description: The military has stepped up a campaign of airstrikes, and killed more civilians, to fend off rebel advances.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: Myanmar Air Force jets performing maneuvers during a celebration last year in Naypyidaw marking the country’s Independence Day.

item.title: Israel, Defiant, Appears to Have Gone Rogue, Risking a Regional War
item.description: Ignoring the efforts of President Biden and the condemnation of many allies, the Israeli prime minister is forcing the pace of the war and feeding the revolt of the far right.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel delivering a speech to Congress in Washington last month.

item.title: Russian Dissident Says He Was Traded Against His Will in Inmate Swap
item.description: Ilya Yashin, a prominent opposition politician, said he appreciated his freedom, but told his jailers he did not want it if it meant going into exile.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ilya Yashin at a news conference on Friday in Bonn, Germany.

item.title: An Autocrat’s Tool Backfires in Venezuela
item.description: Nicolás Maduro claimed victory in his country’s election. But exit polls suggested the opposition leader won a landslide, setting off protests around the country.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An antigovernment protest in downtown Caracas, Venezuela, on Monday.

item.title: Hundreds of Prisoners in Russia, Including Americans, Were Left Behind in Swap
item.description: Hundreds of prisoners — including Americans and Russian political activists — are hoping for a diplomatic agreement that might secure their release.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Anne Fogel, right, reads a letter written by her brother, Marc Fogel, during a rally advocating for his release in Washington in July 2023.

item.title: The Best Conversations
item.description: Whether we’re participating in them or listening to them, the goal is to forget about the outcome and just connect.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Somalia Terror Attack Kills Dozens
item.description: Gunmen and a suicide bomber struck a seaside hotel in one of the deadliest such assaults in the country in months. The Islamist militant group Al Shabab claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Hussein Mohamed
item.media:description: Medics attending the scene on Saturday after an attack at a beach in Mogadishu, Somalia.

item.title: Canadian Doctors Warn Against Private Medicine as a Cure for the System’s Ills
item.description: The Canadian Medical Association has called for a ban on payments for procedures long covered by public systems and is warning about contracting services out.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: In Quebec, doctors have been leaving the public health care system for private clinics.

item.title: Harris Fuels Hope and Skepticism With Georgia’s South Asian Voters
item.description: In Georgia, a critical swing state President Biden won by less than 12,000 votes in 2020, Kamala Harris’ political identity has prompted renewed interest among Asian Americans, the fastest-growing group of eligible voters in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Qian, Alex Pena and Amy Marino

item.title: The Pentagon promises to help defend Israel.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III in Washington in May.

item.title: Equestrian Is Having an Uncomfortable Moment. Its Olympic Horses Are Not.
item.description: Accusations of mistreatment cast a shadow over dressage and other events. Can cooling tents and locally sourced hay change the narrative?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall, Rory Smith and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Marcell Jacobs, Olympic 100-Meter Champion, Looks to Prove the Doubters Wrong
item.description: When the Italian sprinter came from nowhere to win 100-meter gold in Tokyo, whispers spread about his sudden rise. In Paris, he hopes to silence them for good.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Stephanie Gengotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcell Jacobs of Italy is the reigning 100-meter Olympic gold medalist.

item.title: Alongside the Trump-Russia Inquiry, a Lesser-Known Look at Egyptian Influence
item.description: The Justice Department and special counsel Robert Mueller investigated whether a Trump adviser was part of an Egyptian plan, never proven, to funnel $10 million to the 2016 Trump campaign.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Adam Goldman and Glenn Thrush
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump and President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt outside the White House in 2017.

item.title: Prisoner Deals Stoke Fears of Perverse ‘Incentive’ to Grab Americans
item.description: Hostile governments like Russia and Iran are often involved, and practical alternatives are hard to come by, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris greeting prisoners released from Russia on their arrival at Joint Base Andrews on Thursday night.

item.title: Ismail Haniyeh, Hamas Leader, Is Buried in Qatar Amid Mourning in Turkey and Gaza
item.description: Few Palestinians appeared to heed Hamas’s call for a “day of anger” to condemn the killing of Ismail Haniyeh and Israel’s bombardment of the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Victoria Kim and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas supporters paraded on Tuesday in Beirut, Lebanon, with empty coffins in a symbolic funeral for the Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh.

item.title: It’s official: Léon Marchand owns the pool after winning his fourth gold medal.
item.description: After winning the 200 individual medley, Marchand joins Michael Phelps and Mark Spitz as the only male swimmers to win four gold medals at a single Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas and Gabriela Bhaskar
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Sha’Carri Richardson Is Ready for Her Olympic Moment in Paris
item.description: Three years after a failed drug test kept her out of the Olympics, Richardson (and her fans) are focused on only one thing: a gold medal in the 100 meters.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Dodai Stewart
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sha’Carri Richardson: ready to race.

item.title: Maduro Could Remain Venezuela’s President No Matter What Voters Decided
item.description: The Biden administration recognized the autocrat’s rival as the winner of Sunday’s election in Venezuela. Yet President Maduro shows no sign of being willing to leave office.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: National Guard soldiers dispersing a protest on Monday, the day after the election, in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Ippon! Teddy Riner thrills home crowd to grab Olympic gold in judo.
item.description: Facing the No. 1-seeded judoka in the +100kg weight class, Kim Minjong of South Korea, Riner won his sixth Olympic medal.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Iceland’s New President Is a Feminist, and a Friend of Björk
item.description: Though the president’s role is mostly ceremonial, Halla Tómasdóttir said that she would seek to raise “the right questions” and bring attention to critical health issues.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:description: Halla Tomasdottir was sworn into office as Iceland’s president this week. Her incursion in politics has been inspired by the work of women who preceded her, she said.

item.title: The Olympics’ No. 1 Fan
item.description: Is anyone as excited by the Paris Games as Antoine Griezmann? It doesn’t seem possible.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Antoine Griezmann, in white, with President Emmanuel Macron of France and others at the rugby sevens gold medal match last week.

item.title: Police Investigate Death Threats Against Olympics Opening Ceremony Director
item.description: Thomas Jolly said he had received a barrage of online harassment, after some people interpreted a section of the show as mocking a biblical scene.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Jolly has received a barrage of insults and threats online targeting his identity and his sexual orientation.

item.title: Nationwide Protests Over Hunger Rock Nigeria
item.description: Thousands turned out across Africa’s most populous country despite government attempts to prevent them. Demonstrations have left at least 13 people dead, Amnesty International says.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Alfa
item.media:description: Nigerians protesting hunger and inflation on Thursday in Abuja, the capital. Tens of millions of people in Nigeria are struggling to afford food.

item.title: Families of Hostages in Gaza Despair As Assassination Halts Talks
item.description: The recent assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, the leader of Hamas’s political branch, halted negotiations for a cease-fire that would bring home the hostages held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Supporters of the hostages being held in Gaza released 300 lanterns Thursday in Tel Aviv to mark 300 days since the deadly Oct. 7 attack.

item.title: Olympic Officials Defend Fighters’ Eligibility in Women’s Boxing Controversy
item.description: Online fury and unclear rules have left organizers of the women’s boxing competition in Paris facing complex questions about fairness in women’s sports.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman and Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan, right, won a unanimous decision in her debut at the Paris Games.

item.title: Convicted Assassin Is Russian Security Agent, Kremlin Acknowledges
item.description: Vadim Krasikov, who was returned to Russia in the big prisoner swap, received a hero’s welcome from President Putin, along with others who were freed.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: In a photo released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin greeted Vadim Krasikov at Vnukovo International Airport outside Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Is Sending More Combat Aircraft to the Middle East, Officials Say
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III directed the new deployments after speaking with his Israeli counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, seen in South Korea in June, is now steaming near the Arabian Gulf, equipped with about 40 F/A-18 Super Hornet and F-35 attack planes.

item.title: Why Some Young People in China Pretend to Be Birds
item.description: Some people in China flap and squawk on social media as way of escaping hustle culture. We can explain.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Winzar Kakiouea Is a One-Man Team From Nauru. His Olympics Might be Over in 10 Seconds.
item.description: Winzar Kakiouea, a 100-meter runner, is the only competitor at the Paris Games from his Pacific island nation. His debut might be over in a flash.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Winzar Kakiouea will compete in the 100-meter heats on Saturday.

item.title: Champagne, Soft Piano and No Lines: Luxe Life at the Olympics
item.description: A new program allows spectators at the Paris Games to upgrade their seats, eat tastier food, tip glasses of bubbly and avoid the throngs.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spectators in the V.I.P. area of a men’s beach volleyball match on Monday. Those with thousands of euros to spend can sit, eat and travel apart from the masses.

item.title: At a Mountain Retreat, Wine, Lamb Kebabs and Lots of Climate Talk
item.description: Azerbaijan last week convened a special meeting of climate diplomats at a remote resort. A Times reporter was there.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diplomats at the Heads of Delegation retreat were tasked with determining how to disburse huge amounts of money to fight global warming and compensate poor and vulnerable countries that suffer its worst effects.

item.title: Inside Azerbaijan, Host of COP29
item.description: In Azerbaijan, the causes and effects of climate change are on vivid display and the painful trade-offs needed to fight it are acutely felt.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Teenage Talent at the 2024 Olympics
item.description: From the shooting range to the swimming pool, teens and preteens are grabbing medals and the spotlight. Nowhere is this truer than at the skateboard park.
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vareeraya Sukasem, 12, of Thailand in the warm-up before the heats of the women’s street skateboarding competition at La Concorde in Paris.

item.title: Many of Gaza’s Medical Workers Have Been Detained or Killed
item.description: Out of a prewar total of about 20,000 health workers, 500 have been killed in the war, according to the W.H.O., and more than 300 are in Israeli detention, Gaza’s health ministry says.
item.dc:creator: Anjana Sankar
item.media:description: A doctor inspecting damage at Nasser Hospital, in Khan Younis, Gaza.

item.title: Talking Trump and Economics With Joseph Stiglitz in Sydney
item.description: His new book is about reimagining freedom for ‘progressive capitalism.’
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Nobel-winning economist, in Barcelona, Spain, in 2023.

item.title: Talking Trump and Economics With Joseph Stiglitz in Sydney
item.description: The eminent economist describes Donald Trump and the MAGA movement as a response to the failure of nearly 40 years of neoliberalism.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Nobel-winning economist, in Barcelona, Spain, in 2023.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A sweeping prisoner swap between Russia and the West.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden embracing Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter, at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland as Kamala Harris looks on.

item.title: Behind the Prisoner Swap: Spies, a Killer, Secret Messages and Unseen Diplomacy
item.description: The negotiations that led to the prisoner swap and the freeing of Americans wrongfully held in Russia required patience and creativity, but gave both sides what they wanted most.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Anton Troianovski, Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris greeting the freed prisoners at Joint Base Andrews on Thursday night.

item.title: U.S. Recognizes Edmundo González as Winner of Venezuela Election
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said there was “overwhelming evidence” that Edmundo González had won, despite President Nicolás Maduro’s claim of victory.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Edmundo González, the opposition presidential candidate, wearing a blue shirt, stood next to María Corina Machado, a popular opposition leader, at a rally in Caracas, Venezuela, on Tuesday.

item.title: With Russia Prisoner Swap, Biden Scores a Win Near the End of His Term
item.description: The exchange offered a measure of validation for President Biden soon after he abandoned his bid for re-election.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden announced on Thursday at the White House that three American citizens and a U.S. permanent resident freed by Russia were heading home, as their families stood beside him.

item.title: Air Force Finds Mechanical and Crew Failures in Fatal Osprey Crash Last Year
item.description: An investigation determined that missed warning signals and the “catastrophic failure” of a gearbox led to the crash off the coast of Japan in November.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Pieces of a crashed U.S. military Osprey aircraft recovered by a military salvage ship in southwestern Japan last December.

item.title: MrBeast Acknowledges ‘Inappropriate Language’ in Earlier Videos
item.description: A representative for the popular YouTuber said that he was “trying to be funny” and made “bad jokes” in older videos of him that have resurfaced.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: The YouTube personality Jimmy Donaldson, better known as MrBeast, at the Nickelodeon Kids’ Choice Awards in Los Angeles last year.

item.title: Israel Confirms Death of Muhammad Deif, Who It Says Helped Planned Hamas Attack
item.description: The Israeli military said it had killed Muhammad Deif, who it called a planner of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, which would make him the third Iranian-backed militant leader slain in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Farnaz Fassihi, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters on Thursday carried the coffin of a commander, Fuad Shukr, who was killed in an Israeli airstrike in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

item.title: Katie Ledecky’s 13th Olympic medal is a silver, but one for the record books.
item.description: No female American Olympian has won more medals than Ledecky, who swam the third leg for the Americans’ 4x200 freestyle relay team that finished second behind Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, James Hill and Karen Hanley
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Friday Briefing: Evan Gershkovich Freed in a Prisoner Swap
item.description: Plus, how a Hamas leader was assassinated in Iran and a look inside the Olympic Village.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Russian Federal Security Service/RTR, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich on a plane leaving Russia, in an image from video footage provided by the Russian Federal Security Service.

item.title: Vault + bars + beam + floor = gold for Simone Biles.
item.description: Here’s a look at how Simone Biles won the gymnastics all-around gold medal, one routine at a time.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Gabriela Bhaskar, Chang W. Lee and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: Evan Gershkovich and 23 Others Freed From Russian Prisons in Major Swap
item.description: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich was among 24 people released in a seven-nation, painstakingly negotiated deal that President Biden hailed as a triumph of diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich inside an enclosure for defendants before a court hearing in Yekaterinburg, Russia, in June.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich Was Caught in Oppression His Parents Had Fled
item.description: Evan Gershkovich was raised in New Jersey by parents who left the Soviet Union to escape antisemitism and a lack of opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich inside an enclosure for defendants before a court hearing in June in Yekaterinburg, Russia.

item.title: Turkey Revels in the Role It Played in Prisoner Swap
item.description: Turkey has frustrated its NATO allies by often refusing to get tough with Russia, but its good relations with Moscow may have helped it participate in the exchange.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Safak Timur
item.media:description: A Russian plane leaving Ankara Esenboga Airport in Ankara, Turkey, after a major prisoner exchange between Russia, the United States and other countries on Thursday.

item.title: Hezbollah Leader Threatens Retaliation Against Israel After Airstrike Near Beirut
item.description: Nasrallah delivered a televised address at the funeral of a Hezbollah commander who was killed in an Israeli strike in suburban Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, seen on a video screen at the funeral for Fuad Shukr, a Hezbollah commander, in Beirut, Lebanon, on Thursday.

item.title: Pakistanis Rise Up Against Ruling Elite as Misery Multiplies
item.description: Unrest over a range of economic and security issues threatens to deepen the political turmoil that has plagued Pakistan for years.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: A protest against higher electricity bills in Karachi, Pakistan, in July.
